dialogs.original: Stand all apart. Cousin of Buckingham.
dialogs.translated: Everyone stand aside.

dialogs.original: My gracious sovereign.
dialogs.translated: My gracious sovereign.

dialogs.original: Give me thy hand.
dialogs.translated: Give me your hand.

dialogs.original: Thus high, by thy advice    And thy assistance is King Richard seated.    But shall we wear these glories for a day,    Or shall they last and we rejoice in them?
dialogs.translated: I now have this high seat as King Richard because of your advice and assistance. But will I have these glories for a day only, or will they last long enough for me to enjoy them?

dialogs.original: Still live they, and forever let them last.
dialogs.translated: May they live on forever.

dialogs.original: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed.Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.
dialogs.translated: Ah, Buckingham, now I must test you to see if you're true gold indeed. Young Prince Edward is alive. Think about what I might say next.

dialogs.original: Say on, my loving lord.
dialogs.translated: Go on, my loving lord.

dialogs.original: Why, Buckingham, I say I would be king,
dialogs.translated: Why, Buckingham, I said I wanted to be king.

dialogs.original: Why so you are, my thrice-renownèd lord.
dialogs.translated: Why, you are king, my glorious lord.

dialogs.original: Ha! Am I king? 'Tis sobut Edward lives.
dialogs.translated: Ha! Am I king? Perhaps it's sobut Edward still lives.

dialogs.original: True, noble prince.
dialogs.translated: True, noble prince.

dialogs.original: O bitter consequence    That Edward still should live true noble prince!    Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.    Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead,    And I would have it suddenly performed.    What sayest thou now? Speak suddenly. Be brief.
dialogs.translated: Oh, what a bitter conclusion that Edward should still live as the "true, noble prince!" Cousin, you didn't use to be so stupid. Shall I speak plainly? I want the bastards dead, and I want it done immediately. What do you say now? Speak quickly, and be brief.

dialogs.original: Your Grace may do your pleasure.
dialogs.translated: Your Grace can do as he pleases.

dialogs.original: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?
dialogs.translated: Tut, tut, you've grown icy. Your kindness freezes over. Tell me, do you agree that they must die?

dialogs.original: Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord,Before I positively speak in this.I will resolve you herein presently.
dialogs.translated: Give me a moment to breathe, dear lord, a pause before I make a statement. I'll give you my answer shortly.

dialogs.original: [aside to the other attendants]  The king is angry. See, he gnaws his lip.
dialogs.translated: [To the attendants so that only they can hear]The king is angry. See how he bites his lip.

dialogs.original: [aside]    I will converse with iron-witted fools    And unrespective boys.   None are for me    That look into me with considerate eyes.    High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.    Boy!
dialogs.translated: [To himself] I only want to deal with unfeeling fools and careless boys. I want nothing to do with anyone who can read me well. Ambitious Buckingham is growing too thoughtful.

dialogs.original: [coming forward]  My lord?
dialogs.translated: [Coming forward] My lord?

dialogs.original: Knowst thou not any whom corrupting goldWill tempt unto a close exploit of death?
dialogs.translated: Do you know anyone who can be tempted with gold into secretly killing someone?

dialogs.original: I know a discontented gentleman    Whose humble means match not his haughty spirit.    Gold were as good as twenty orators,    And will, no doubt, tempt him to anything.
dialogs.translated: I know one unhappy gentleman whose empty wallet doesn't match his proud spirit. Gold is better than twenty speeches, and will, no doubt, tempt him to do anything.

dialogs.original: What is his name?
dialogs.translated: What is his name?

dialogs.original: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
dialogs.translated: His name is Tyrrel, my lord.

dialogs.original: I partly know the man. Go, call him hither, boy
dialogs.translated: I know the man a little. Go, call him here, boy.

dialogs.original: [aside]    The deep-revolving witty Buckingham    No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels    Hath he so long held out with me, untired,    And stops he now for breath? Well, be it so.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] The deep-thinking, clever Buckingham will no longer be privy to my plots. Has he run with me for so long, only to stop for a "moment to breathe" now? Well, so be it.

dialogs.original: How now, Lord Stanley, whats the news?
dialogs.translated: Hello, Lord Stanley, what's the news?

dialogs.original: Know, my loving lord,The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.
dialogs.translated: You should know, my loving lord: I've heard that the Marquess of Dorset has fled to Richmond in France.

dialogs.original: Come hither, Catesby. Rumor it abroad    That Anne my wife is very grievous sick.    I will take order for her keeping close.    Enquire me out some mean poor gentleman,    Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter.    The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.    Look how thou dreamst! I say again, give out    That Anne my queen is sick and like to die.    About it, for it stands me much upon    To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
dialogs.translated: Come here, Catesby. Spread around a rumor that my wife Anne is very sick. I will make arrangements for keeping her locked up. And find me some poor gentleman whom I can marry straight away to Clarence's daughter. Clarence's son is an idiot, so I'm not afraid of him. But look at you daydreaming! I say again: spread the rumor that Anne, my queen, is sick and likely to die. Hurry upit's very important that I destroy anything that might come to damage me.

dialogs.original: [aside]    I must be married to my brothers daughter,    Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.    Murder her brothers, and then marry her    Uncertain way of gain.   But I am in    So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin.    Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] I must marry my brother Edward's daughter, or else my kingdom is only standing on fragile glass. Murder her brothers, and then marry herit's a strange way to go about things. But I'm so steeped in blood at this point that one sin must follow another. These eyes of mine have no tears of pity.

dialogs.original: Is thy name Tyrrel?
dialogs.translated: Is your name Tyrrel?

dialogs.original: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
dialogs.translated: James Tyrrel, your most obedient subject.

dialogs.original: Art thou indeed?
dialogs.translated: Are you indeed?

dialogs.original: Prove me, my gracious lord.
dialogs.translated: Let me prove it, my gracious lord.

dialogs.original: Darst thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
dialogs.translated: Would you dare to kill a friend of mine?

dialogs.original: Please you. But I had rather kill two enemies.
dialogs.translated: If it would please you. But I would rather kill two enemies.

dialogs.original: Why then, thou hast it. Two deep enemies,    Foes to my rest, and my sweet sleeps disturbers,    Are they that I would have thee deal upon.    Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.
dialogs.translated: Well, you can do that then. I want you to kill two great enemies of mine, enemies of my sleep and my peace of mind. Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

dialogs.original: Let me have open means to come to them,And soon Ill rid you from the fear of them.
dialogs.translated: Let me have free access to reach them, and soon you won't have to fear them anymore.

dialogs.original: Thou singst sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel.
dialogs.translated: Your words are sweet music. Come here, Tyrrel.

dialogs.original: Go, by this token. Rise, and lend thine ear.
dialogs.translated: Go, with this password. Rise and listen.

dialogs.original: There is no more but so. Say it is done,And I will love thee and prefer thee for it.
dialogs.translated: There's nothing more than that. When you tell me the deed is done, I will love you and promote you for it.

dialogs.original: I will dispatch it straight.
dialogs.translated: I'll do it straight away.

dialogs.original: My lord, I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in.
dialogs.translated: My lord, I've been considering the request you just asked me about.

dialogs.original: Well, let that rest. Dorset is fled to Richmond.
dialogs.translated: Well, forget about that. Dorset has fled to join Richmond.

dialogs.original: I hear the news, my lord.
dialogs.translated: I heard that news, my lord.

dialogs.original: Stanley, he is your wifes son. Well, look unto it.
dialogs.translated: Stanley, Richmond is your wife's son. Well, find out what she knows.

dialogs.original: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise,    For which your honor and your faith is pawned    Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables    Which you promisèd I shall possess.
dialogs.translated: My lord, I want to claim the gift you promised me on your honor and faiththe earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it, which you swore that I would have.

dialogs.original: Stanley, look to your wife. If she conveyLetters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
dialogs.translated: Stanley, watch your wife. If she sends any letters to Richmond, you will answer for it.

dialogs.original: What says your Highness to my just request?
dialogs.translated: What does your Highness say to my just request?

dialogs.original: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth    Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,    When Richmond was a little peevish boy.    A king, perhaps
dialogs.translated: I remember that Henry the Sixth prophesied that Richmond would be king one day, when Richmond was only a foolish boy. A king, perhaps

dialogs.original: My lord
dialogs.translated: My lord

dialogs.original: How chance the prophet could not at that timeHave told me, I being by, that I should kill him?
dialogs.translated: But why wasn't the prophet able to foresee that I, who was there at the time, would kill him?

dialogs.original: My lord, your promise for the earldom
dialogs.translated: My lord, your promise of the earldom

dialogs.original: Richmond? When last I was at Exeter,    The mayor in courtesy showed me the castle    And called it Rougemont,   at which name I started,    Because a bard of Ireland told me once    I should not live long after I saw Richmond.
dialogs.translated: Richmond? The last time I was in Exeter, the mayor politely showed me a castle and called it "Rougemont." The name startled me, for an Irish poet once told me that I wouldn't live long after seeing Richmond.

dialogs.original: My Lord
dialogs.translated: My lord

dialogs.original: Ay, whats o'clock?
dialogs.translated: Hey, what time is it?

dialogs.original: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mindOf what you promised me.
dialogs.translated: I am reminding your Grace of what you promised me.

dialogs.original: Well, but whats o'clock?
dialogs.translated: Well, but what time is it?

dialogs.original: Upon the stroke of ten.
dialogs.translated: Almost ten o'clock.

dialogs.original: Well, let it strike.
dialogs.translated: Well, let it strike ten then.

dialogs.original: Why let it strike?
dialogs.translated: Why "let it strike?"

dialogs.original: Because that, like a jack, thou keepst the strokeBetwixt thy begging and my meditation.I am not in the giving vein today.
dialogs.translated: Because you're like the peasant who strikes the bell, interrupting my thoughts with your begging. I'm not in the giving mood today.

dialogs.original: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.
dialogs.translated: Well then, give me a final answer of whether I'll have the earldom or not.

dialogs.original: Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein.
dialogs.translated: You're annoying me. I'm not in the mood.

dialogs.original: And is it thus? Repays he my deep service    With such deep contempt? Made I him king for this?    O, let me think on Hastings and be gone    To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
dialogs.translated: Is this how it is? He rewards my great service with such great contempt? Did I make him king for this? Oh, let me learn from Hastings and hurry away to Brecknock, while my frightened head is still on my shoulders!
